spans.text: declination is given with a decimal
If the MD given on the map is recorded as a decimal, for example 23Â°,5 W, you must
multiply the number after the comma by 6
to convert it to minutes. For example:
5 Ã 6 = 30â. So, the MD is now 23Â°30â W. The decimal comma has been removed and
you have a MD in degrees and minutes.
Now look at the following worked example:
Mean magnetic declination (MD) 18Âº,3 west of true north (1985.01)
MD = 18Â°,3 W of TN = 18Â° 18â W of TN
Once you have done your calculation, if the magnetic declination for the current year has
minutes greater than 59â you need to convert the minutes to degrees.
76â â 60â leaves 16â. The 60 minutes you subtracted equal 1 degree, which you add to
Now look at the following worked example:
Mean magnetic declination (MD) 31Âº 33â west of true north (1990.08)

  Worked example 3: If the magnetic 
declination is given with a decimal 
place instead of minutes
If the MD given on the map is recorded as a decimal, for example 23Â°,5 W, you must 
multiply the number after the comma by 6 to convert it to minutes. For example: 
5 Ã 6 = 30â. So, the MD is now 23Â°30â W. The decimal comma has been removed and 
you have a MD in degrees and minutes.
Now look at the following worked example:
Mean magnetic declination (MD) 18Âº,3 west of true north (1985.01)
Mean annual change (AC) 1â westwards (1980â1990)
MD
TN
MN
Calculating magnetic declination for 2012
MD = 18Â°,3 W of TN = 18Â° 18â W of TN
AC = 1â W
2012 â 1985 = 27 years 
27 Ã 1â W = 27â W
MD = 18Â° 18â W + 27â W = 18Â° 45â W of TN
PAY SPECIAL ATTENTION

exams
  Worked example 4: If the magnetic 
declination answer has the minutes 
greater than 59â
Once you have done your calculation, if the magnetic declination for the current year has 
minutes greater than 59â you need to convert the minutes to degrees.
For example: MD = 23Â° 76â
76â â 60â leaves 16â. The 60 minutes you subtracted equal 1 degree, which you add to 
the 23Â° to get 24Â° 16â.
Now look at the following worked example:
Mean magnetic declination (MD) 31Âº 33â west of true north (1990.08)
Mean annual change (AC) 2â westwards (1987â1993)
Remember that  
1Â° = 60â (1 degree =  
60 minutes)

Remember that  
1Â° = 60â (1 degree =  
60 minutes)

  Worked example 3: If the magnetic 
declination is given with a decimal 
place instead of minutes
If the MD given on the map is recorded as a decimal, for example 23Â°,5 W, you must 
multiply the number after the comma by 6 to convert it to minutes. For example: 
5 Ã 6 = 30â. So, the MD is now 23Â°30â W. The decimal comma has been removed and 
you have a MD in degrees and minutes.
Now look at the following worked example:
Mean magnetic declination (MD) 18Âº,3 west of true north (1985.01)
Mean annual change (AC) 1â westwards (1980â1990)
MD
TN
MN
Calculating magnetic declination for 2012
MD = 18Â°,3 W of TN = 18Â° 18â W of TN
AC = 1â W
2012 â 1985 = 27 years 
27 Ã 1â W = 27â W
MD = 18Â° 18â W + 27â W = 18Â° 45â W of TN

  Worked example 4: If the magnetic 
declination answer has the minutes 
greater than 59â
Once you have done your calculation, if the magnetic declination for the current year has 
minutes greater than 59â you need to convert the minutes to degrees.
For example: MD = 23Â° 76â
76â â 60â leaves 16â. The 60 minutes you subtracted equal 1 degree, which you add to 
the 23Â° to get 24Â° 16â.
Now look at the following worked example:
Mean magnetic declination (MD) 31Âº 33â west of true north (1990.08)
